heading.title: PART 20 RESOLUTION OF PROCEEDINGS WITHOUT HEARING [rr 20.1–20.34]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 20 RESOLUTION OF PROCEEDINGS WITHOUT HEARING [rr 20.1–20.34]

p.text: Legislation cited in [Note] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 42.13 to 42.17.

This Division is intended to facilitate the early compromise of proceedings. It does so by allowing parties to make formal offers of settlement which, though unable to be disclosed in the litigation of the substantive issues between the parties, can be taken into account in relation to costs. A party that has made an appropriate offer of compromise is ordinarily entitled to a special costs order if the final judgment is not less favourable than the offer. The Division is complemented by rr 42.13 to 42.17 , which set out the principles relating to the making of appropriate costs orders where formal offers have been made under the rules, but not accepted.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.26] r 20.26 Making of offer (cf SCR Part 22, rules 1A, 2, 3 and 4; DCR Part 19A, rules 1, 2, 2A, 3 and 4; LCR Part 17A, rules 2 and 5)

leg:heading.title: Making of offer (cf SCR Part 22, rules 1A, 2, 3 and 4; DCR Part 19A, rules 1, 2, 2A, 3 and 4; LCR Part 17A, rules 2 and 5)

p.text: In any proceedings, any party may, by notice in writing, make an offer to any other party to compromise any claim in the proceedings, either in whole or in part, on specified terms.
An offer under this rule:
must identify:
the claim or part of the claim to which it relates, and
the proposed orders for disposal of the claim or part of the claim, including, if a monetary judgment is proposed, the amount of that monetary judgment, and
if the offer relates only to part of a claim in the proceedings, must include a statement:
in the case of an offer by the plaintiff, as to whether the balance of the proceedings is to be abandoned or pursued, or
in the case of an offer by a defendant, as to whether the balance of the proceedings will be defended or conceded, and
must not include an amount for costs and must not be expressed to be inclusive of costs, and
must bear a statement to the effect that the offer is made in accordance with these rules, and
if the offeror has made or been ordered to make an interim payment to the offeree, must state whether or not the offer is in addition to that interim payment, and
must specify the period of time within which the offer is open for acceptance.
[subr (2) subst SI 259 of 2013 Sch 1[4], effective 7 June 2013]
An offer under this rule may propose:
a judgment in favour of the defendant:
with no order as to costs, or
despite subruleÂ (2)(c) , with a term of the offer that the defendant will pay to the plaintiff a specified sum in respect of the plaintiff’s costs, or
that the costs as agreed or assessed up to the time the offer was made will be paid by the offeror, or
that the costs as agreed or assessed on the ordinary basis or on the indemnity basis will be met out of a specified estate, notional estate or fund identified in the offer.
[subr (3) subst SI 259 of 2013 Sch 1[4], effective 7 June 2013]

If the offeror makes an offer before the offeree has been given such particulars of the offeror’s claim, and copies or originals of such documents available to the offeror, as are necessary to enable the offeree to fully consider the offer, the offeree may, within 14 days of receiving the offer, give notice to the offeror that:
the offeree is unable to assess the reasonableness of the offer because of the lack of particulars or documents, and
in the event that ruleÂ 42.14 applies to the proceedings, the offeree will seek an order of the court under ruleÂ 42.14(2) .
[subr (4) subst SI 259 of 2013 Sch 1[4], effective 7 June 2013]
The closing date for acceptance of an offer:
in the case of an offer made two months or more before the date set down for commencement of the trial — is to be no less than 28Â days after the date on which the offer is made, and
in any other case — is to be such date as is reasonable in the circumstances.
[subr (5) subst SI 259 of 2013 Sch 1[4], effective 7 June 2013]
[subr (6) rep SI 259 of 2013 Sch 1[4], effective 7 June 2013]
[subr (7) rep SI 259 of 2013 Sch 1[4], effective 7 June 2013]

Unless the notice of offer otherwise provides, an offer providing for the payment of money, or the doing of any other act, is taken to provide for the payment of that money, or the doing of that act, within 28 days after acceptance of the offer.
An offer is taken to have been made without prejudice, unless the notice of offer otherwise provides.
A party may make more than one offer in relation to the same claim.
Unless the court orders otherwise, an offer may not be withdrawn during the period of acceptance for the offer.
A notice of offer that purports to exclude, modify or restrict the operation of ruleÂ 42.14 or 42.15 is of no effect for the purposes of this Division.

In order to be a valid offer under this part, the form and terms of the offer must be in accordance with the rules: Melville v Tadros (NSW(CA), 21 May 1999, unreported, BC9902780). The offer should specifically announce that it is an offer of compromise under these provisions of the rules: Uniting Church in Australia Property Trust (NSW) t/as Northaven Retirement Village v Takacs (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 172; BC200806906 at [6] and [7]Â (“offer of Compromise” referred to in UCPR Pt 20 without specific reference to UCPR r 20.26 — sufficiently made in accordance with “these rules”); Kain v Mobbs (No 2) [2008] NSWSC 599; BC200804584 at [7]Â (offer with general reference to “the rules” not an offer to which the rules applied).
Legislation cited in [20.26.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 20.26, UCPR r 20.26(2), UCPR rrÂ 42.14-42.15A.

An offer of compromise that does not comply with UCPR r 20.26 does not attract the potential costs consequences provided for in UCPR rrÂ 42.14-42.15A , but it may, nevertheless, take effect as a Calderbank offer: Trustee for the Salvation Army (NSW) Property Trust t/as Salvation Army v Becker [2007] NSWCA 194; BC200706430 atÂ [24]Â (offer expressed to be inclusive of costs did not comply with UCPR r 20.26(2) — explicit alternative claim to be a Calderbank offer). Unless an informal offer of compromise involves some direct inconsistency with the formal “offer of compromise” rules of court, the courts are likely to regard the content and terms of such an offer as relevant to the exercise of the costs discretion: see Elite Protective Personnel Pty Ltd v Salmon [2007] NSWCA 322; BC200709738 at [133]–[135]Â : see further [42.13.15]. If the offer is inconsistent with the Rules (because, for example, it is inclusive of costs) its relevance to the exercise of the costs discretion turns on the court’s satisfaction that it was intended to operate as a Calderbank offer: Old vÂ McInnes [2011] NSWCA 410; BC201110349 atÂ [106]Â (no explicit claim — offer irrelevant).
Legislation cited in [20.26.8] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 20.26(2), UCPR rr 42.14, 42.15.

Apart from the specific provision in UCPR r 20.26(2) (verdict for the defendant and no order for the payment of costs) a complying offer of compromise cannot be made on terms that are either inclusive of costs or otherwise restrict the operation of the special costs rules in UCPR rr 42.14 and 42.15 : Ngo v Fenech [1999] NSWCA 219; BC9903620Â . This prohibition against including costs in the offer of compromise applies to:

offers involving a monetary sum: Dean vÂ Stockland Property Management Pty Ltd (NoÂ 2) [2010] NSWCA 141; BC201004114Â atÂ [23]; Vieira vÂ O’Shea (NoÂ 2) [2012] NSWCA 121; BC201202853Â (offer of monetary sum, did not state it was “exclusive of the costs” — court held statement was unnecessary — it was for the court to determine if in fact the offer was exclusive of costs, because the effect offer “…will be to engage the relevant costs rule in PtÂ 42” atÂ [13]) and
offers involving other terms: Trustee for the Salvation Army (NSW) Property Trust t/as Salvation Army v Becker (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 194; BC200706430Â .
Consequently, the following kinds of offers have been held not to be complying offers of compromise under the rules:

an offer of a money sum and an identified sum for costs: Penrith Rugby League Club Ltd (t/as Cardiff Panthers) v Elliot (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 356; BC200909906Â (offer to pay $5,000 in damages and $8,000 for costs and disbursements); Tarabay v Fifty Property Investments Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 951; BC200908776Â (offer to pay $8,500 plus $1,500 for costs);

defendant’s offer of a verdict and judgment for the defendant with plaintiff to pay 50% of defendant’s costs: Frisbo Holdings Pty Ltd v Austin Australia Pty Ltd (No 2) [2010] NSWSC 298; BC201002372Â ;
offer of dismissal of the appeal and an order that costs be paid out of the estate of the deceased: Trustee for the Salvation Army (NSW) Property Trust t/as Salvation Army v Becker (No 2), above; and
offer to compromise appeal on terms (1) new trial and (2) each party to pay own costs of appeal: Dean v Stockland Property Management Pty Ltd (No 2), above, at [30].

level.toc-caption: [20.26.9] Offers “plus costs as agreed or assessed”

p.text: Legislation cited in [20.26.9] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 20.26(2).

heading.title: Offers “plus costs as agreed or assessed”

p.text: It is clear from the authorities cited in [20.26.8] above that an offer of compromise is not “exclusive of costs” (as required by UCPR rÂ 20.26(2) ) if it includes any specific provision for the payment of costs. In some instances it has been held that an offer to pay costs “as agreed or assessed” was not “exclusive of costs” and did not comply with UCPR rÂ 20.26(2) : Old vÂ McInnes [2011] NSWCA 410; BC201110349Â — followed in Re Cheal Industries Pty Ltd; Fitzpatrick vÂ Cheal [2012] NSWSC 932; BC201206355Â .

Other cases have held that an offer containing such a reference to costs was a complying offer — because it merely anticipated, and clarified the intended application of the rules that would ordinarily apply to acceptance of the offer: Dean vÂ Stockland Property Management Pty Ltd (NoÂ 2) [2010] NSWCA 141; BC201004114Â ; Vieira vÂ O’Shea (NoÂ 2) [2012] NSWCA 121; BC201202853Â (“a mere reference to costs in an offer otherwise compliant with PtÂ 20, DivÂ 4 will not take the offer outside the rules unless the reference operates inconsistently with the relevant costs rule”). The latter decisions are at least consistent with numerous instances in which offers of compromise containing expressions such as “plus costs” have been regarded as complying offers: The Anderson Group Pty Ltd vÂ Tynan Motors Pty Ltd (NoÂ 2) (2006) 67 NSWLR 706; [2006] NSWCA 120; BC200603504Â (offer provided that “costs [of proceedings] to be agreed or assessed”); Ambulance Service of New South Wales vÂ Worley (NoÂ 2) (2006) 67 NSWLR 719; [2006] NSWCA 236; BC200606639Â (offer of judgment for $1.5m plus costs); Macquarie Radio Network Pty Ltd vÂ Dent (NoÂ 2) [2007] NSWCA 339; BC200710315Â (offer to accept $70,000 plus costs); San vÂ Rumble (NoÂ 2) (2007) 48 MVR 492; [2007] NSWCA 259; BC200708156Â (offers to pay a sum plus costs); Uniting Church vÂ Takacs (NoÂ 2) [2008] NSWCA 172; BC200806906Â (offer to pay a judgment sum plus the plaintiff’s costs).

In Rail Corp NSW vÂ Vero Insurance Ltd (NoÂ 2) [2012] NSWSC 926; BC201206350Â GarlingÂ J reviewed the many, not entirely consistent, decisions. The judge concluded the better view was that an offer plus “costs and disbursements as agreed or assessed” was a complying offer for the purposes of UCPR rÂ 20.26(2) — because it was not inconsistent with the ordinary application of the rules: see Rail Corp NSW vÂ Vero Insurance Ltd (NoÂ 2) [2012] NSWSC 926; BC201206350 atÂ [85]–[99]Â . Other first instance decisions have come to the same view in relation to similar offers: Collins v Sydney Ports Corp [2012] NSWSC 1316; BC201210524 atÂ [43]–[44]Â (Offer expressed to be “plus costs” — no conflict between a requirement that an offer must be made exclusive of costs and an offer that is expressed in terms of a particular sum plus costs — complying offer); Ziliotto vÂ Harkim (NoÂ 2) [2012] NSWSC 1079; BC201208607 atÂ [8]–[32]Â (offer provides for payment of specified amount “plus costs as agreed or assessed” — complying offer); Orcher vÂ Bowcliff Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 1429; BC201209135 atÂ [11]Â (Offer: “plus costs as agreed or assessed” — does not operate inconsistently with the relevant costs rule); for discussion of the divergent authorities.
Legislation cited in [20.26.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.13.

The offer of compromise procedure is intended to encourage parties to a true compromise of the dispute between them. The associated inducements and costs sanctions in r 42.13 are intended to ensure that the offers made are reasonable, and reflect a fair and proper compromise, rather than the best result that a party could hope to obtain. The offer of compromise procedure is not intended to be utilised simply as a statutory demand whose rejection would automatically entail the payment of costs on an indemnity basis. To be an “offer of compromise” under this rule some real element of compromise must be involved in the offer: Tickell v Trifleska Pty Ltd (1990) 25 NSWLR 353Â ; Hobartville Stud Pty Ltd v Union Insurance Co Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 358Â . An offer to accept full payment of a claim is not a compromise: Richardson v Hough [1999] NSWSC 448; BC9902286Â . But what constitutes a compromise involves an impressionistic judgment that depends on the totality of the circumstances: Shellharbour City Council v Johnson (No 2) (2006) 67 NSWLR 308; [2006] NSWCA 114; BC200605024Â at [20]–[23] (offer representing 91% of modest judgment amount). The rules do not require that the offer is substantially less than the amount claimed or recovered. For example, in Forbes Services Memorial Club Ltd v Hodge (NSWCA, 8 March 1995, unreported, BC9504456) the court held that an offer to compromise an appeal for an amount only $129.24 less than the trial judgment was a sufficient compromise having regard to the slight prospects of success in the appeal.
Note: The appropriate exercise of the costs discretion, where the final judgment is only marginally more favourable than an offer of compromise, is discussed further at [42.13.13] .

A party contemplating making use of an offer of compromise procedure should also consider making a Calderbank offer: Skinner & Edwards (Builders) Pty Ltd v Australian Telecommunications Corp (1992) 27 NSWLR 567Â . Whether an avowedly formal, but non-complying, offer of compromise can be taken into account as a Calderbank offer, depends on the terms of the offer: Trustee for the Salvation Army (NSW) Property Trust v Becker [2007] NSWCA 194; BC200706430 at [27]Â (offer inclusive of costs of proceedings – took effect as a Calderbank offer). The principles governing the admissibility of “without prejudice” offers in relation to the exercise of the costs discretion are discussed in [21.5.135]–[21.5.145] and [42.13.25]–[42.13.30] .

An offer of compromise may be made under the present rule even if it does not relate to all claims for relief in the proceedings: Herbert (bht Meehan) vÂ Tamworth City Council (NoÂ 4) (2004) 60 NSWLR 476; [2004] NSWSC 394; BC200402656Â (matter determined as a separate question in the proceedings); and even in respect of a defendant's pleaded entitlement to set-off: Whitehouse Properties Pty Ltd v Bond Brewing (NSW) Ltd (1992) 28 NSWLR 17Â . If the offer is only addressed to one of several parties, it must be capable of individual acceptance by that party: Vieira v O’Shea (NoÂ 2) [2012] NSWCA 121; BC201202853Â atÂ [13]. If the offer is expressed to apply to a plaintiff's singular claim, and there are multiple claims pleaded, the offer operates made with respect to any claim within the meaning of rule: Antoniadis v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (SC(NSW), Levine J, Nos 11047/90 and 14914/91, 24 April 1997, unreported, BC9701476) (three separate instances of defamation alleged in the statement of claim). Even in the case of offers made by way of a Calderbank letter (see [42.13.25] ) the fact that the offer relates only to one of various claims does not prevent the successful offeror from obtaining a special costs order from the date of the offer: Magenta Nominees Pty Ltd v Richard Ellis (WA) Pty Ltd [1994] FCA 302; BC9405976Â .
An offer of compromise made to one party may be expressed to be conditional on the acceptance of another offer made to a third party: Oxlade v Gosbridge Pty Ltd (No 2) [1999] NSWCA 165; BC9903593Â .
Legislation cited in [20.26.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 20.26(10).

Rule 20.26(10) specifically permits parties to make more than one offer of compromise. Where this occurs, and a lesser judgment is ultimately obtained, the party who made the offers will be entitled to a costs order from the date of the first offer that was “not less favourable” than the actual judgment. The making of successive offers does not deprive a party of the potential costs benefit that arises where the offer is not accepted within the time provided for in the rules: Hillier v Sheather (1995) 36 NSWLR 414; BC9504564Â .
Legislation cited in [20.26.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.26(11).

The principles that govern the exercise of the court’s powers under r 20.26(11) are similar to those that are applied to the withdrawal of moneys brought into court under the former rules. Under those rules a defendant was not entitled as of right to withdraw money paid into court. Ordinarily it was necessary to establish a proper reason for the application to withdraw for example a complete change in the complexion of the case brought about by the discovery of new evidence or a recent judicial decision: Cumper v Pothecary [1941] 2 KB 58Â ; WA Sherratt Ltd v John Bromley (Church Stretton) Ltd [1985] 1 QB 1038. Money paid into court on a mistaken meaning of the statement of claim was permitted to be withdrawn: Kaprow and Co Ltd v Maclelland and Co Ltd [1948] 1 KB 618; [1948] 1 All ER 264Â . An offer of compromise made by mistake was permitted to be withdrawn even after its purported acceptance, where the fact of the mistake should have been apparent to the acceptor: Lewis v Combell Constructions Pty Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 528Â ; Young v Combe (NSWSC, Hodgson J, No 3254/90, 29 July 1993, unreported, BC9301813) (application to withdraw when offer accepted after late service of additional affidavit evidence); Scanruby Pty Ltd v Caltex Petroleum Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 411; BC200102605Â (additional evidence discovered after offer made); Hutchinson v Myer Stores Ltd (1995) 184 LSJS 398Â (offer obviously excessive and made by mistake). Leave was also given where an amendment to the pleadings raised an insuperable obstacle to the plaintiff’s claim (Frazer and Haws Ltd v Burns (1934) 49 Ll L Rep 216Â ; Williams v Boag [1941] 1 KB 1; [1940] 4 All ER 246Â ); and where the cause of action abated on the death of the plaintiff: Singer v Gilchrist Watt and Sanderson Pty Ltd (1950) 67 WN (NSW) 89Â ; cf Maxwell v Wolseley [1907] 1 KB 274Â .

However, leave to withdraw may be refused where the offer was made (and there was no evidence of genuine mistake) despite the plaintiff’s failure to comply with a merely procedural pre-condition to the commencement of proceedings: Berowra Holdings Pty Ltd v Gordon (2006) 225 CLR 364; 228 ALR 387; [2006] HCA 32; BC200604256Â (failure to give 6-months notice before commencement of proceedings).

level.toc-caption: [20.26.40] Reasonableness of the time for acceptance

p.text: Legislation cited in [20.26.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 20.26(7), rrÂ 42.14, 42.15.

heading.title: Reasonableness of the time for acceptance

p.text: Where the offer is made less than 2Â months before the trial of the proceedings it must be left open for "such time as is reasonable in the circumstances". The circumstances relevant to the assessment of what constitutes "reasonable time" will include all the information available to the parties, including any relevant change of circumstances. It will also include awareness of the provisions of rrÂ 42.14 andÂ 42.15 — which permit indemnity costs orders in relation to costs incurred from the day following the date the offer was made. The mere fact that a late offer is only left open for a few days will not necessarily preclude compliance with the "reasonable time" requirement of rÂ 20.26(7) : Leda v Weerden (NoÂ 3) [2006] NSWSC 220; BC200602050Â . On the other hand, if the offer is made very close to trial, and provides only a short time for acceptance, the competing practical exigencies of both completing final preparation for hearing, and giving prompt consideration to the offer may suffice to preclude characterization of the acceptance period as reasonable: Kooee Communications Pty Ltd v Primus Telecommunications Pty Ltd (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 85; BC200803122 at [18]–[24]Â (offer day before trial – 22 hour acceptance period – not reasonable acceptance period).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.27] r 20.27 Acceptance of offer (cf SCR Part 22, rule 3; DCR Part 19A, rule 3; LCR Part 17A, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Acceptance of offer (cf SCR Part 22, rule 3; DCR Part 19A, rule 3; LCR Part 17A, rule 5)

p.text: A party may accept an offer by serving written notice of acceptance on the offeror at any time during the period of acceptance for the offer.
An offer may be accepted even if a further offer is made during the period of acceptance for the first offer.
If an offer is accepted in accordance with this rule, any party to the compromise may apply for judgment to be entered accordingly.

Any communication that would constitute a contractual acceptance under the general law will suffice as acceptance under the present rule. Notice of acceptance will be effective if it is communicated to the offeror, even if the mode of communication does not constitute formal service in accordance with rÂ 10.5 : Mohamed v Farah [2004] NSWSC 482; BC200403298Â .

level.toc-caption: [20.27.7] Entry of judgment in accordance with accepted offer

p.text: Legislation cited in [20.27.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Part 20, Div 4, rÂ 20.27.

heading.title: Entry of judgment in accordance with accepted offer

p.text: Part 20, Div 4 provides for the resolution of proceedings by compromise without a hearing. Rule 20.27 permits either party to apply for judgment to be entered in accordance with the terms of an accepted offer of compromise. The rule provides the parties with the procedural means to bring formal finality to the claim (in light of the general rule that the court ordinarily has no power to set aside a final judgment once it has been passed and entered: see [36.16.10] ). Such finality could not be achieved by mere dismissal, discontinuance or stay: Dawson v ACP Publishing Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 542; BC200704185Â (offer of compromise accepted, plaintiff entitled to entry of judgment although “judgment” amount had already been paid).
Legislation cited in [20.27.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 42.13A.

If a complying Offer of Compromise is accepted the Plaintiff is entitled to an order for costs on the ordinary basis unless (i) the offer was a verdict the defendant and on terms that each party bear their own costs, or (ii) the court otherwise orders: UCPR r 42.13A ; Cumper v Pothecary [1941] 2 KB 58Â ; Lomer v Waters [1898] 2Â QB 326; Wiltshire Bacon Co Ltd v Associated Cinema Properties Ltd [1938] Ch 268; [1937] 4 All ER 80Â . It is difficult to envisage any circumstances in which an offeror plaintiff would be deprived of the benefit of the costs orders contemplated by the rules, or have that entitlement enlarged. The same applies to a plaintiff who accepts a defendant’s offer. If the accepted offer involves a verdict for the defendant and provides for each party to bear their own costs, a plaintiff would have no real basis for having the court make any different costs order.
Legislation cited in [20.27.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR rÂ 20.26(4), UCPR rr 42.14–42.15A, UCPR rÂ 42.15, UCPR r 42.15A.

UCPR rr 42.14–42.15A contain costs provisions that apply, in the absence of any contrary order, where unaccepted offers of compromise have been made in proceedings. A successful plaintiff who makes an offer of compromise, and obtains a judgment that is no less favourable than the terms of the offer of compromise, is entitled to costs on an indemnity basis from the day after the date of the offer: UCPR rÂ 42.14 ; X v Pal (NSWCA, Mahoney, Clarke and Meagher JJA, No 40190/90, 7 June 1991, unreported, BC9101914). A successful plaintiff who ultimately obtains a judgment that is no more favourable than the terms of a defendant’s offer, will only be entitled to an order for costs up to and including the date of the offer. Thereafter, the defendant offeror will be entitled to an order for costs against the plaintiff: UCPR rÂ 42.15 . Conversely, a successful defendant who obtains a judgment or order that is no less favourable than their unaccepted offer will also be entitled to indemnity costs from the day after the date of the offer: UCPR r 42.15A .

Because of the effect of these provisions of the rules, legal practitioners have a duty to give realistic consideration to offers of compromise. The Court of Appeal emphasised that obligation in: Maitland Hospital v Fisher (No 2) (1992) 27 NSWLR 721 at 725; BC9201767Â . There the Court of Appeal said that the special costs rules were expected to apply “in the ordinary case”. That “ordinary case” includes (subject to UCPR rÂ 20.26(4) ) situations where a party has acted reasonably in rejecting an offer of compromise: NSW Insurance Ministerial Corporation v Reeve (1993) 42 NSWLR 100Â . Indeed it has been said that the rules confer a “prima facie” entitlement to special costs orders: Morgan v Johnson (1998) 44 NSWLR 578 at 581–582; BC9804556Â ; and that “compelling” or “exceptional” circumstances would be required to justify a departure from the special costs rules: Hillier v Sheather (1995) 36 NSWLR 414 at 422B-E; BC9504564Â per Kirby P; South Eastern Area Health Service v King [2006] NSWCA 2; BC200600916 at [83]Â per Hunt AJA; Caine v Lumley General Insurance Ltd (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 109; BC200803845 at [35]–[37]Â per Basten JA. (These general considerations are discussed further in [42.14.10] .) However in Maitland Hospital v Fisher (No 2) and somewhat elliptically, the Court of Appeal added that the rules conferred an overriding costs discretion that had to be exercised according to “all the circumstances of the case, not by applying a fixed mathematical formula”. The application of these general principles can present particular difficulties where the final judgment (whether in favour of a plaintiff or a defendant) is only marginally more favourable than the unaccepted offer. Those situations are discussed further in [20.26.10] and [42.13.13] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.28] r 20.28 Withdrawal of acceptance (cf SCR Part 22, rule 5; DCR Part 19A, rule 5; LCR Part 17A, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Withdrawal of acceptance (cf SCR Part 22, rule 5; DCR Part 19A, rule 5; LCR Part 17A, rule 7)

p.text: A party who accepts an offer may withdraw the acceptance in any of the following circumstances by serving written notice of withdrawal on the offeror:

if the offer provides for payment of money, or the doing of any other act, and the sum is not paid to the offeree or into court, or the act is not done, within 28Â days after acceptance of the offer or within such other time as the offer provides, or
if the court grants the party leave to withdraw the acceptance.
If acceptance of an offer is withdrawn:
except as provided by paragraph (b), all steps in the proceedings that have been taken as a consequence of the offer having been accepted cease to have effect, and
the court may give directions:
to restore the parties as nearly as may be to their positions at the time of the acceptance, and
to give effect to any steps in the proceedings that have been taken as a consequence of the offer having been accepted, and
to provide for the further conduct of the proceedings,
and may do so either after the offer is withdrawn or when granting leave to withdraw the offer.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.28(1)(b).

The rules make clear that the offer of compromise is a wholly procedural device. In this they mirror the approach that was taken under the payment in procedure: Cumper v Pothecary [1941] 2 KB 58 at 67Â . Accordingly under r 20.28(1)(b) , the court may give leave to withdraw acceptance of an offer. There was a similar discretion under the earlier rules and it is likely that similar principles will apply. As a general rule (and apart from the case of delay contemplated by r 20.28(1)(a)), it is to be expected that the court will not grant leave unless there is good reason to permit a party to retract acceptance — such as fraud: (Derrick v Williams [1939] 2 All ER 559Â ; Knight v Burgess [1972] ALR 628Â ); or mistake: Edelsten v Cookson (1888) 14 VLR 810Â ; Kaprow and Co Ltd v Maclelland and Co Ltd [1948] 1 KB 618; [1948] 1 All ER 264Â ; Gainsborough Mixed Concrete Ltd v Duplex Petrol Installations Ltd [1968] 3 All ER 267.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.29] r 20.29 Failure to comply with accepted offer (cf SCR Part 22, rule 8; DCR Part 19A, rule 8; LCR Part 17A, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Failure to comply with accepted offer (cf SCR Part 22, rule 8; DCR Part 19A, rule 8; LCR Part 17A, rule 10)

p.text: If the plaintiff, being a party to an accepted offer, fails to comply with the terms of the offer, the defendant is entitled:
to such judgment or order as is appropriate to give effect to the terms of the accepted offer, or
to an order that the proceedings be dismissed, and to judgment accordingly,
as the defendant elects, unless the court orders otherwise.
If the defendant, being a party to an accepted offer, fails to comply with the terms of the offer, the plaintiff is entitled:
to such judgment or order as is appropriate to give effect to the terms of the accepted offer, or
to an order that the defence be struck out, and to judgment accordingly,
as the plaintiff elects, unless the court orders otherwise.

If a party to an accepted offer fails to comply with the terms of the offer, and a defendant in the proceedings has made a statement of cross-claim or cross-summons that is not the subject of the accepted offer, the court:
may make such order or give such judgment under this rule, and
may make such order as to the further conduct of proceedings on the statement of cross-claim or cross-summons,
as it thinks fit.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.30] r 20.30 Disclosure of offer to court or arbitrator (cf SCR PartÂ 22, ruleÂ 7; DCR PartÂ 19A, rule 7; LCR Part 17A, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Disclosure of offer to court or arbitrator (cf SCR PartÂ 22, ruleÂ 7; DCR PartÂ 19A, rule 7; LCR Part 17A, rule 9)

p.text: No statement of the fact that an offer has been made may be contained in any pleading or affidavit.
If an offer is not accepted, no communication with respect to the offer may be made to the court at the trial or, as the case may require, to the arbitrator.
Despite subrule (2), an offer may be disclosed to the court or, as the case may require, to the arbitrator:
if a notice of offer provides that the offer is not made without prejudice, or
to the extent necessary to enable the offer to be taken into account for the purpose of determining an amount of interest up to judgment, or
after all questions of liability and relief have been determined, to the extent necessary to determine questions as to costs, or

to the extent necessary to enable the offer to be taken into account for the purposes of sectionÂ 73(4) of the Motor Accidents Act 1988, sectionÂ 137(4) of the Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999 or sectionÂ 151M of the Workers Compensation Act 1987.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 20.26(9), UCPR r 26.1(11).
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 131.

The prohibition against the disclosure of the offer mirrors the position under the former rules: Bonitto v Fuerst Bros & Co Ltd [1944] AC 75; [1944] 1 All ER 91Â ; Monk v Redwing Aircraft Co Ltd [1942] 1 KB 182; [1942] 1 All ER 133Â . The rule does not expressly prevent disclosure at interlocutory applications, but the offer is to be taken to have been made “without prejudice” unless it provides to the contrary: rÂ 20.26(9) . As such the offer is inadmissible (Evidence Act 1995 s 131 ); both at the trial and at an interlocutory hearing in the proceedings: Macplan Logistic Systems Pty Ltd v Baxter Healthcare Pty Ltd (1996) 39 NSWLR 324Â (security for costs application); Simaan General Contracting Co v Pilkington Glass Ltd [1987] 1 All ER 345; [1987] 1 WLR 516Â . The rule does not prevent disclosure:
of the fact of the communication in which the offer is made: Hoefler v Tomlinson (1995) 60 FCR 452; 133 ALR 625Â (disclosure relevant to show awareness of the proceedings).
associated with an interlocutory application for leave in relation to the offer – for example, leave to withdraw under UCPR r 26.1(11) .
after all questions of liability and relief have been determined: Scope Data Systems Pty Ltd v Agostini Jarrett Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 971; BC200707361Â (disclosure after leave to discontinue); or

on an appeal: Bonitto v Fuerst Bros & Co Ltd , above; although where the appeal is as to quantum it is desirable that there be no disclosure of the amount of the offer: Mason v Mason [1965] 3 All ER 492; [1966] 1 WLR 767; Thornton v Swan Hunter (Shipbuilders) Ltd [1971] 3 All ER 1248; [1971] 1 WLR 767.

Breach of the prohibition against disclosure could result in the trial judge refusing to continue to hear the case but there is a discretion to permit the hearing to continue: Millenstead v Grosvenor House (Park Lane) Ltd [1937] 1 KB 717Â ; Harvey v Harvey [1965] QWN 41Â ; Murphy v Murphy [1963] VR 610Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.31] r 20.31 Compromises in certain Supreme Court proceedings (cf SCR Part 8, ruleÂ 14)

leg:heading.title: Compromises in certain Supreme Court proceedings (cf SCR Part 8, ruleÂ 14)

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court concerning:
the administration of a deceased person’s estate, or
property the subject of a trust, or
the construction of an Act, instrument or other document,
involving any matter in which one or more persons have the same interest or liability.
The court may approve a compromise:
that one party has assented to, or
that the court has sanctioned on behalf of one party,

being in either case a compromise that affects other persons (not being parties) having the same interest or liability, but only if the court is satisfied that the compromise will be to the benefit of those other persons.
A compromise referred to in subrule (2) binds the absent persons unless the court’s approval of the compromise has been obtained by fraud or non-disclosure of material facts.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.32] r 20.32 Offer to contribute (cf SCR Part 22, ruleÂ 12; DCR PartÂ 19A, ruleÂ 11; LCR Part 17A, rule 13)

leg:heading.title: Offer to contribute (cf SCR Part 22, ruleÂ 12; DCR PartÂ 19A, ruleÂ 11; LCR Part 17A, rule 13)

p.text: If in any proceedings:

one party (the first party) stands to be held liable to another party (the second party) to contribute towards any debt or damages which may be recovered against the second party in the proceedings, and
the first party, at any time after entering an appearance, makes an offer to the second party to contribute to a specified extent to the debt or damages, and
the offer is made without prejudice to the first party’s defence,
the offer must not be brought to the attention of the court or any arbitrator until all questions of liability or amount of debt or damages have been decided.
In subrule (1), debt or damages includes any interest up to judgment claimed on any debt or damages.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.26, r 42.18.

The present rule is intended to facilitate resolution of issues between parties who face potential liability (either directly as defendants, or indirectly, as cross defendants) as to part of the plaintiff’s claim. The rule implicitly recognises that resolution of those issues may also facilitate the resolution of the whole of the plaintiff’s claim. The rule permits any of the potentially liable parties to make an offer to contribute (specified as either an amount or as a proportion) towards satisfaction of the plaintiff’s claim. Making such an offer does not involve, or require, any admission of liability to the plaintiff: Henderson v Simon Engineering (Aust) Pty Ltd [1988] VR 867 at 871Â . Where an offer of contribution is made in accordance with the rule, the court must take the offer into account in making orders relating to the costs of the proceedings: see r 42.18 . In contrast to the provisions of r 20.26 , no particular formalities relate to the making of an offer to contribute. And although it would be prudent for any such notice to make clear that it is made under the present rule and for the purpose of enlivening the costs discretion under r 42.18, it has been held that even informal contribution offers may properly be taken into account in the exercise of the costs discretion: VSLR Pty Ltd (formerly Venture Stores (Retailers) Pty Ltd) v Sefa (VSC App Div, Brooking, Ormiston and Nathan JJ, 26 July 1995, unreported, BC9503827).
